**Does this make whiteboards superior to screencasting or vice versa?** No, it doesn’t. Each have their distinct advantages. With the **white board**, you can more easily sell the material to students, which is important for **abstract concepts**. With **screencasting**, you can give **live recordings aplications**. The white board should only be used for live recordings when talking about something like mock white board interviews.

When I watched the original videos of me writing the notes while I was lecturing, and compared it to the videos I’m shooting now, they seem far more distracting. So, **to summarize, if it is written on a board, you MUST have everythin written prior to recording.**

He also has all of his notes in front of him, which gives him confidence throughout the video. And finally, he is quite relaxed, which is probably from years of lecturing. @/all Hi everyone, some people have asked why we record the videos the way we do (a person talking in front of a whiteboard, and with screencasts as necessary). @brianamarie did it that way because it seemed natural to her as a teacher, and because that's how MOOCs mainly did it. But I wondered if that was actually the optimal way. So I spent a few hours doing some research and here's what I found out:

There are no widely cited papers focused on the efficacy of lecturing in YouTube videos. 

I conducted a Twitter poll 
https://twitter.com/ossia/status/774077365014061056

I asked on Quora question: https://www.quora.com/Which-format-works-best-for-short-YouTube-lectures-drawing-on-a-whiteboard-or-using-a-slide-deck-with-a-green-screen

(I'm a fan of whiteboarding, so I hope I didn't somehow bias the responses with the way I worded these questions.)

I also went through a ranked list of educational youtube channels and found no correlation behind their approach and production values and their results (views, subscribers). Here are some examples:

The New Boston (1m subscribers - screencast): https://www.youtube.com/user/thenewboston

Khan Academy (2.5m subscribers - digital whiteboard): https://www.youtube.com/user/khanacademy

Programming Knowledge (250k subscribers - screencast): https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCs6nmQViDpUw0nuIx9c_WvA

Computerphile (650k subscribers - talking and writing stuff down on paper): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_jKylhJtPmI

MIT Open Courseware (1m subscribers - standing at the whiteboard): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xw3ccgYhFis&index=5&list=PLUl4u3cNGP63oTpyxCMLKt_JmB0WtSZfG

My conclusions: 
- production value doesn't seem to matter (none of the top educational channels used green screens or fancy visual effects)
- the presentation doesn't have to be perfect - far from it. The more natural and casual it seems, the better.
- the quality of content seems to be the main thing that matters.
